revised_title: Effect of Hydrostatic Pressure on the Uniaxial Creep Life of a 2% Cr 1% Mo Steel
tldr: This study investigates the impact of hydrostatic pressure on the ductility, creep life, and failure mechanism of a 2% Cr 1% Mo steel under different uniaxial stresses. The research found that increasing hydrostatic pressure led to increased creep ductility and a decrease in cavitation, resulting in a longer time to failure. The results are discussed in terms of a diffusional cavity growth model that includes continuous nucleation and compared with data from single-phase materials tested under similar conditions. The study also examines the role of principal and equivalent stresses in the creep fracture of the steel and discusses the estimation of long-term creep life from short-term creep tests.
